div.head: EGYPTIAN POLITICS.
div.p: The Cairo Correspondent of the "Daily Telegraph" contributes the following article to that journal:-

The Egyptian National Party looms so largely on the horizon nowadays, that it is, perhaps, advisable to attempt to discover what the real aims of the party, which Mustapha Pasha Kamel professes to lead, really are, and what the character and moral code are of the people, whom they declare are both anxious and fit to govern themselves, by means of representatives elected by the people.
The Egyptian is extremely delightful, and

has a great many very admirable qualities, but in mental habit and moral outlook he is the exact opposite of the European. His ideas of honour and honesty are by no means those of the Western nations; he is not yet sufficiently highly educated, and has not yet come frequently enough into daily contact with the representatives of Western civilisation in his midst to realise that another point of view not only exists but is lived up to. The Egyptian always searches for a hidden motive, and he credits those who are only striving to improve his government or his surroundings with being either entirely selfish or else work ing in some seeret way to do him harm. Few schemes are mooted for the betterment of the Fellah "Al i some similar paper, este 4 for the aggrandisement «r to further the interests of the official who is responsible for them. This is one of the main causes of the heart-sickness and discouragement from which Egyptian officials so often suffer.

The difference of their moral code may he judged from the fact that it is by no means considered a disgrace for an Egyptian to go to prison ; while there he walks hand in hand and in intimate converse with his gaoler, and when he is released his family and friends welcome him warmly; no special stigma attached itself to being sent to gaol, it is merely a not altogether unpleasant incident, for he is well-fed and clothes. Indeed, so much is it a fact that it is not considered a disgrace that a police officer was very atixions to arrange a marriage his daughter and the son of Minshawi while the latter was in prison for attempting 'to murder his father.

The following case may give some idea of what constitutes a crime. A man in the provinces had made a considerable sum of money by selling the same piece of land three times over; when the case came before the Courts it was found very difficult to discover the truth, but his son, under examination, admitted what had really happened, and he, because he had told the truth and assisted the ends of justice, was looked upon as an outcast and unworthy of consideration.

What sort ot goveroment would it be when these are the ideas of right and wrong held by the majority of the nation | However will the real voice of the nation be discovered! For « village will andoubtedly vote according to the wishes of their omdeh, or head man ; the system of representative government is entirely foreign to their habit of mind and to their social system. The Bedouin would not certsinly submit to be governed by the Egyptian, and would therefore have to be given an eqnal voice in the Government.

The majority of the Egyptians have really no political convictions at all ; as long as their land is improved by irrigation they are content to work and prosper ; but as a nation they are affected a hundred times more by words than by deeds, and they are extraordinarily snsegp- tible to flattery. Tee tole tuiageifpt'way "be be considered one of self-glorification, for the newspapers are full of praise of the Egyptian, how fine he is, and how infinitely more fit to govern he is than are his present governors, instead of pointing out his weak points and suggesting improvement.
Why should the Egyptian be more capable of governing himself than the Turk?

The argument is often urged the speeches which the supporters of tian nationalism make are not worth noticing, because of the relative unimportance of the speakers ; this is, however, unfortunately, not true, for every.small utterance in their favour is quoted by the Nationalist Press, and its author glorified until the Fellah, who has no other soureé of information, believes that the real public opinion of England is in favour of granting self-government to Too mach importance cannot be to the influence the Nationalist Preas has in this country. Ac- cusations against English officials are hurled broadcast, and these steries, absurd as they often seem to English ears, are implicitly believed, because the Englishman is too proud and conscious of his own rectitude to deny them.

Western education has accomplished much in Egypt, and is daily improving, and its sphere of inflaence widening, but it has been in opera- tion merely for the space of one generation, ®0 that the Egyptians have only a voneer of Western cultivation ; they have by no means reached that pitéh of education from which all good representative government must start, the knowledge to appreciate their own ignorance.

For those who believein the disinterestedness of the self-styled Egyptian patriot, Mr. Wilfred Blunt's book on the Arabi rebellion would be a not noprofitable study ; the way in which pro- minent men changed from Arabi to his High- ness Tewfik Pasha, as their interests dictated, is extremely illuminating. In most cases in the world's history ardent patriots have sacri- ficed all for love of their country, and lived and died in poverty. In Egypt many of these patriots who started life as poor men are already rich.

One of the latest and perhaps the most dangerous, in its possible consequences to Egypt, of the cries of the Nationalist party ia the demand for the exolusion of the Syrians. This agitation is the more dangerous as its main-spring is jealousy ; the Syrian is a very cultivated and useful member of society, and owing to his capacity for work and knowledge ot langaages he occupies many of the minor Government posts, the Nationalist contends, to the exclusion of the Egyptian ; they do not consider that the Syrian is more useful, and that usefulness is the primary consideration in engaging a Government official, and that the best way to turn the Syrian out is to qualify themselves to fill the same posts equally well.
This cry has, however, aroused all the deepest feelings of hatred which the Egyptian seems always to have cherished, in a greater or lesser degree, against the Syrian.

div.head: Bubonic Plague
div.p: There are five cases of plague under treatment at Port Said.

div.head: New Public Buildings
div.p: The total credit asked for by the Towns and State Buildings Department for new constructions is L.E. 500,000.

div.head: Legislative Council
div.p: The Legislative council will assemble under the presidency of Abdel Hamid Pasha Sadik on Saturday to consider the revision of the Criminal Code.

div.head: Public Health Department.
div.p: Dr. Georges S. Cephalonitis, Benedetto Moise and Philippe Tsacuoglou, and Mr. Lambros Hadji Antonoglou, veterinary surgeon have been authorised to practise in Egypt.

div.head: Locusts in the South
div.p: Locust have appeared in Kassala and Dongola Provinces. We learn also that large numbers appeared at Kawa, White Nile Province, and were successfully driven off by the people.

div.head: Malaria at Kassala
div.p: Many cases of malarial fever are reported from Kassala. The civil hospital is full with patients, and there are no less than 140 or 150 cases in the military hospital. No morality is said, however, to result from the fever.

div.head: Mohamed Aly Anniversary.
div.p: On the fourteenth day of Ramadah the Wakts Administration will celebrate the anniversary of the death of Mohamed Aly by the religious service at the Cairo Citadel Mosque. Prince Mohamed Aly Pasha will represent the Khedive.

div.head: Sudan Telephones
div.p: The number of trunk lines of the telephone service between Khartoum and Omdurman will be increased to five; and between Khartoum and Khartoum North, to three. A direct line will be established between Khartoum North and Omdurman. These new lines will no doubt greatly improve the service.

div.head: Rodah Bridge Incident.
div.p: In regard to the regrettable incident which occurred at the Rodah Bridge, there appears to be an impression that the chief engineer representing the firm of Sir William Arroll was the agressor. This however was not the case, the gentleman in question not being present at the time at all, and no members of the firm of Arroll were implicated in any way.

div.head: New Map of Egypt
div.p: A new map to the scale of 50,000 is in course of preparation by the Survey Department. It will embrace the whole of the cultivable land lying between Cairo and Assouan, and also a part of the Delta. This map, which is distinct from the only recently published, will be issued both in English and Arabic, during the early part of next year.

div.head: Things Seen in Egypt
div.p: "Things Seen in Egypt," by Clive Holland, is one of Messrs. Seeley and Co.'s charming "Portfolio Monographs" series. It is prettily bound in decorated blue, will gilt tops, and Mr. Holland's text which describes Cairo and Nile, ancient monuments, social and city life, and country ways and scenes, is illustrated by fifty beautiful photographs. The size of the book is a small pocket octavo.

div.head: The Cities of the Egyptian Sultans.
div.p: Professor Margoliouth, Landian Professor of Arabic at Oxford, has written a book on the three chief cities of the Egyptian Sultans, Cairo, Jerusalem and Damascus. It is fully illustrated in colour after water-colour drawings by W.S.S. Tyrwhitt, R.B.A.,with additional plates after paintings by Reginald Barratt, A.R.W.S., and from line drawings.

div.head: Honeymooning on the Nile.
div.p: The latest idea is to break the tedium of the solitary honeymoon by taking it in company with other couples on the same sweet errand. From a duet the honeymoon is to be turned into a chorus. In the middle of November three smart weddings are to take place on three consecutive days in London. On the fourth all three couples, who are, of course, intimate friends, all moving in the same set, are to meet in Paris, and to travel together to Egypt. From Cairo their purpose is to hire a dehabeah to sail up the Nile as far as the second cataract. Maids and valets will acoompany the party. The three happy couples have imposed but one restriction on their perfect freedom. It is, "no bridge before breakfast."

div.p: Apres midi de 4 a 6 heures, concert sur la terrasse du Casino execute par l'excellent orchestre Hackmayer, deja si connu a Alex andrie. div.head: POSITION OF MANCHESTER BANKS.
div.p: The Manchester correspondent of the "Financial Times" states that on inquiry in authoritative quarters in banking and financial circles in Manchester he found that objection is taken to seme references in the Press to Manchester's connection with the Egyptian trade failure. He was assured in high quarters not only that the total commitment of all the Manchester banks in the matter cannot be anything like three quarters of a million—a figure which has been mentioned—but that no one institution is involved to the extent of a tenth of thatsum One hundred thousand of the total amount involved is owing on the Continent, and in any case when credit is taken for sequrities held by the banks the Joss per institution is, comparatively speaking, like- ly to be a flea bite. It is also added that the liabilities in question are well spread and that the spinners and manufacturers of the amnty are not now pulling on the banks for credit facilities, so that they have plenty of liquid resources at their disposal.

div.head: CAIRO SYNDICATE LIMITED
div.p: The following paragraph appears in the "Financial News" of the 10th inst:-

A meeting of the shareholders of the Cairo Syndicate, Limited, was held at 46, Dover- street, Piccadilly, W., for the purpose—so we are informed by a shareholder—of considering the alvisability of making certain changes in the directorate. Our representative, however, was told by the secretary that the meeting was strictly private and that the proceedings were of a purely formal nature. Which of these versions is the more accurate we cannot pretend to state. It is one of the conse quences of these secret meetings that con jectural and often inconsistent versions of their subject matter get into cirenlation

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive, who has return from a short visit to Mariout, will give a banquet to night at Ras-el-Tin to several notables of Alexandria.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL DECORATIONS.
div.p: The Khedive has conferred the rank of Mirmiran on Anguste Adib Pasha, Director General of State Acconnts ; the rank of Montamaiz on Hussein Magdi Bey, ex chief engineer of the northern section of the Behera provinee | and the rank of Sanieh on [brahim Zeki Bey, ex chief engineer of Ghizeh province; Ali Zakai Bey, ex chiet engineer of the first section of Neneh provinee , Ahmed Fathi Bey, | ex judge of the Keneh Native Tribunal ; and Ahined*Hamdi Mohamed Bey, ex professor of mathematics at Mansourah school

div.head: AHMED DJELALLEDIN PASHA
div.p: Much comment is made in Cairo and Alex- andria oon the special telegram which we published on the DP5th inst reporting the desire of the Sultan that Alimed Djelalledin Pasha should return to Constantinople. It is generally believed here among native politic- iang that the Pasha will accede to the Snitan's demand on the conditions that
(1) he should have full liberty and that his safety should be guaranteed:
(2) he should be appointed to an important post in the Government service:
(3) he should be permitted to take an annual holiday with full rights of the travel in any country.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The S.S. "Carib Prince" with passengers and general cargo, left Manchester on the 13th inst., and is due to arrive at Alexandria on or about the 29th.
The S.S. "Merchant Prince," with passengers and general cargo, left Malta on the 16th inst., and is due to arrive at Alexandria on Sunday morning.
The Papayanni liner "Arabian" left Malta this morning and is due here on the 20th inst. with passengers and mails.
The Papayanni liner "City of Bombay" left Liverpool yesterday morning for Alexandria.

div.head: EGYPTIAN STATE TELEGRAPHS.
PETITION FROM STAFF.
div.p: We have received the following letter from the employes of the Cairo office of the Egyptian State Telegraphs:-

Sir,— We the undersigned, State Telegraph Staff, have learnt that the Government em- ployés will shortly be granted a month extra Pay, asa temporary step in view to enabling them to facetheextraordinary costof livelihood pending the final putting in torce of the new regulations anent their cadres, We do not doubt that the news of this grant will be heard with joy by all concerned. We await confirma- tion of it, however, with a certain anxiety which is inspired by our sad experience of last year, when a similar gratuity was offered to all Government staffs except the Railway Admi- nistration. But we then abstained from ex- pressing our complaints. We had hoped that there would have been some special arrange- ments for us; but we regret to say that, as far as we are concerned, very little or nothing has been donetowards the bettering of our lot which has become worse than ever, except those few favoured by chance. Others were silented in their dissatisfaction with petty increases (nite inadequate to the state of things in the country, while many other unfortunate men, | who had had not one penny increase for years, were once more deceived in their cheerful hopes. We leave it to you to imagine, Sir, how intense our disappointment then was, and we cannot understand for what reasons we have been deprived of the extra allowance of a month's pay last year. Are we not Government employés! Are we henceforth to consider ourselves men like the employés of the Water and Gas Companies? We now beg to refer you to our petition of the 10th December, 1906, in which we have tried to give a superficial idea of our sufferings and the hardships ot our service with salaries quite insufficient consider- ing the present expensive life, which has made of us proletarians. Needless to say more. We only hope that our legitimate grievances will be listened to with justice, that we shall not be excluded from this year's gratuity, that increases will be equal to everyone according tothe number of one's years of service, especially to those of our poor colleagues, whose salaries have not heen increased for years. We also entertain the hope that an exceptional pension law will be bestowed upon us. These ate our claims, unexaggerated in compartson with the nature of oar work. We would beg you to kindly take these claims into consideration, as our diseontent has no bounds, and it most have its serious conseqnences: namely the downheartedness of our staff, etc

div.head: EGYPTIAN CIVIL SERVICE
div.p: The number of Oxford graduates required for the Egyptian Civil Service this year has been reduced to three. It is the general opinion that the number of university graduates required in future will not be so large as hitherto.

Right English inspectors arrived last week at Khartoum to fill posts in the Sudan Inspectorate. They have now been placed in dif- ferent Government offices, where they will pass abont two months, after which they will he sent to the provinces as inspectors.
The Cairo correspondent of the "Globe," says:-

Reports, well authenticated, in circles where the Anglo-Egyptian officials who rule Egypt do work and congregate, make it clear that the Iitherto unfailing annual importation of Englishmen to join their forces to the Egyptian service will not, for the first time, take place this year.
It therefore seems fairly certain that Sir Eldon Gorst means to make a serious begin ning in the attempt at leading the Egyptians hy slow stages to the point of governing them. selves.

The step is a momentous one to take and the experiment is, of course, not only the most interesting essay in our pelicy in Egypt for alongtime, but it is also the most daring. That is all the more so in view of one of Lord Cromers parting messages. It was a mild protést against criticiam or condemnation of the staffing of the Egyptian services by English men. Lord Cromer stated he thought it not desirable, and, indeed, not possible, to effect an immediate reduction in their numbers.
Instead of being overstaffed, the Khedive's service, he considered, was in some instances undermanned as far as the Européan staff was concerned, and the latter woul bave to be Increased.

div.head: ASSOUAN DISCOVERIES.
div.p: M. Clermont-Ganneau, who has been ex- cavating in Egypt at Elephantine, near the first cataract, has made some important and interesting discoveries. After a few days work the burial place of the rams, sacred to the god Khnum, was bronght to light and a number of inummies of these animals still in their granite sarcopbagi were discovered. The bandages on the mummies were profusely decorated with mythologjeal scenes and inscriptions. Two large diorite statnes of Thothmes II. covered with hieroglyphies were also found on this site.

M. Clermont Ganneau has also collected a large number of inscriptions in hieroglyphic, hieratic, demotic Greek, and Coptic for the most part written on pieces of pottery and known to scholars as ''ostraka." Some letters written in Aramaic were also found, and these establish beyond doubt the presence of Ara- mean Jews at Elephantine about the fifth century B.C. Thanks to this discovery we may now hcpe to find the remains of the sanctuary to Jehovah, which is said to have existed at Elophantine in the time of Darius, Artaxerxes, and Xerxes.

div.head: CRUISING YACHT "VECTIS"
div.p: Port Said, Tuesday.

The P. and 0. cruising yacht "Veotis" arrived here at 7 am. this morning from Jaffa, which post she left yesterday afternoon. The "Veotis" has been specially fitted up aaan ocean-oruising yacht and this is the tenth cruise she has made as such. On leaving Marseilles on the 3rd inst. she had 80 pas sengers on boaid, 50 of whom stayed in Syria and Palestine, Only six passengers disembarked here for Cairo and these left by the mid-day train and will rejoin the yacht at Alexandria on Thursday the 24th. The "Vectis" will leave here to-morrow at noonand proceed to Beyrout, Haifa, and Jaffa to re-embark those who have made excursions in Palestine ; from Jaffa she will return to Egypt, this time calling at Alex- andria, where a five days' stay will be made. in ving Alexandria the yacht will return 7 Syracuse, Naples and Marseilles.

div.head: The "Amphitrite."
div.p: H.M.S. "Amphitrite," first class cruiser, arrived here this morning and entered the Canal almost immediately.

div.head: The Casino.
div.p: On Saturday next the proprietors of the Casino are giving a grand ball, to celebrate the closing of the Casino for the winter season. Messrs. Simonini Bros. are to be congratulated on the succesa of their adventure, the Casino has proved to be a great success this summer and the residents are truly thankful for what has long been wanted, a nice, cool, clean spot where one can sit out during the hot summer months.

div.head: The Passenger Season.
div.p: The passenger season is in full swing now and our streets are fairly packed with passengers both day and night. Prices of goods are up 50% and the hotels are kept busy catering.

div.head: The S.S. "Macedonia."
div.p: The mail boat "Macedonia," commander C. D. Bennett, arrived here soon after 1 p.m. with 5500dd passenzers, of which 58 disembark- ed here for Egypt and the Sudan. Amongst those to disembark were Sir M. Mollwraith, and Mr. and Mrs. Aziz Kahil Bey. A cricket match was arranged between the passengers and the club team and a very interesting afternoon's sport was obtained. The start of the match was not made till 3 pm. Port Said were not at their full strength, the principal absentees being Macdonald, Tweedie (Jnnr) and A. V. Wallis, the latter unfortunately having dislocated his thamb in the match against the P.and 0. "Arabia" last month. The visitors batted first, sending Waller and Beynon in to face the bowling of Williams and King. These two batsmen put on 51 rans before they were parted, Beynon being well caught by -Newbould in the long field. The credit. White, who had relieved King at the top end, was now replaced by Tweedie, and in his first over Waller was caught by Field at cover point. Field well deserved the applause he received, his catch being quite the feature of the game. Waller in his innings ot 65 only gave one chance and that was a difficult one to point. With six wickets down the passengers declared their innings closed, léaving Port Said with only 45 minutes to play. Tweedie and Williams were first partners for Port Said and both players hit out freely, but with the score at 25 Williams was canght and bowled. De Rougemont joined Tweedie and these two players were still batting when stumps were drawn. Tweedie was very lucky early in his innings, two catches being dropped off his bat, and this proved a very expensive let off as will he seen by the score :—
White, Newbould, Field, Imgram, King, Hayward, and Back did not bat.

div.head: Passengers from Brindisi.
div.p: Port Said, Wednesday.

The RMS. "Isis," Capt. A.B. Armitage, arrived here just before 4 o'clock this morning. Amongst the passengers to disembark here were:—Sir W. Garstin, A. Chitty Bey, Messrs Lawrence, E. Bounas, W.R.S. Bond, W. T.| Hume, Baron de Kusel, N. Mayne, J.C. Mac Kendrick, Stirling, A.L.C. Stuart Thubron, Hart, A.N. Fane, Whitton, G.J. Swann, Hodson, Speir, Gandohfi Maloney, Capt. Whisham, Capt. Newcombe, Mr. and Mra. Hooker and Capt. Midwinter.

div.head: THE Hotel Casino San Stefano
div.p: Will be open during Winter
REDUCED PRICES

div.head: WINSTON CHURCHILL'S VISIT.
div.p: The event of the moment is the vitit to the Island of Mr Winston Churchill. Heisthe first high Colonial Office official and prominent member of the British Government to visit Cyprus during term of office, and the Cypriot people are consequently worked up into a state of considerable excitement. The local papers are, and for some tiine past have been, filled with leading articles, open letters and correspondence and so forth, discussing the political meaning of and the probable results that will flow from his visit. Parochial polities have a habit of assuming an intensity out of all proportion to theirreal importance. Infinites imally small as the questions may appear which inflame and engross the minds of local politicians when compared with the world- wide interests which have to be considered by Imperial statesmen, yet these questions are often of vital importance to the welfare of those whom they directly concern. Cypros has her needs, real and imaginary, and doubtless Mr. Charehill will hear # good deal of both daring his short stay. His time will be very tully oceupied. He arrived on board H.M.8. "Venus" early yesterday morning at Famagusta, where. he was received by the High Commissioner, who liad proceeded there overnight. He received deputations from both the Turkish and between them on the question of precedence. Some disturbarice took place but, 'apparently, of no very serious consequence. A visit was paid to the extremely interesting old fortified town, so rich in medieval and if interest and historical associations. The harboar works and newly constructed quay were also inspected, and the afternoon was occupied in the railway journey to Nicosia. Large crowds had collected at the Nicosia terminus, Greek flags were flying in all directions, and almost every carriage and every individual native carried one. Hundreds of school children lined the appron lies to the station, and very pretty and effective they looked in the glow of the setting son 'The blne and white of the waving flags fluttering in the breeze gave an animated whole scene, which, from an artistic point of view, made amends for the conspicnaus absence of the Union Jack. A dinner party was given last night at Govern- ment House to which were a a few English officials add +} ladies, the elected members of the Legislative Codneil other notables of the native communities. afternoon.an "At Home" was given at the honse of Mrs. Clauson, wife of the iy Seeretary, which was largely attended English officials and others. Mr. Chutebill is expected to visit Kyrenia and to rejoin his vessel at Larnaca on Sunday. Thence he will proceed to Limassol before finally leaving the Island.

div.head: Price of Cereals.
div.p: Price of cereals continue to rise with unabated regularity. A quantity of wheat has changed hands at 5/- per kilo, and barley at 2/4 1/2 cp, and even 3/- per kilo. The price of flour has consequently risen also and charcoal has done the same. Bread is therefore likely to be dear. The pressure which this causes upon the limited incomes of these who are not producers or merchants is becoming acute.

div.head: Murder of a Muleteer.
div.p: A brutal murder took place on the Ist September last. Kadir Said, a well known mnuleteer of Limassol, was shot, stabbed and robbed near the Ay Brini Khan in that die- trict, A reward of £50 is now offered for information that will lead to the apprehension and conviction of the guilty parties.

div.head: Movements of Troops.
div.p: The troops on leaving Troodos will return direct to camp at Polemedia, near Limassol, and will not undertake any march round the Island.

div.head: Omodhos Animal Show.
div.p: As was anticipated the Omodhos Animal Show on 27th September was not very suc- cessful. Only 21 horses and 19 donkeys were exhibited as against 86 horses and 24 donkeys last year. The class for the donkeys was so poor that the third prize was withheld. Nor was the quality of the animals shown equal to that of recent years. Ihe judging was undertaken by Mr. C. 8. Cade, Acting Hon. Sec. to the Cyprus Stock Committee, Mr. Harvey, Gov. Vet. Surg. and Mr. I. Wodehouse—Cypras Mil. Police. As already explained a week or two ago the departure of the visitors to Troodos taking place before the date of this fixture was calculated to reduce both the namber of entries and the attendance.

div.head: CAIRO'S DRAINAGE.
div.p: To The Editor of The "Egyptian Gazette."
Truly Yours,
Mike Robe.
Cairo, 15th October.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Prince Hussein Pasha Kamel arrived in Paris from Biarrit at the end of last week.
Prince Djemal Pasha Toussoun left for Austria yesterday by the S.S. "Schleswig."
The Sirdar will leave for the Sudan on the 2nd prox. Sir Rudolph von Slatin Pasha is leaving next week. The Sirdar inspected the Cairo Garrison this morning.
Sir William Garstin arrived at Cairo last night from Europe.

As announced in a previous issue Mr. E. Alexander Powell, U.S.A. Consul, Alexandria, has returned from his joliday and the offices of the American Consulate have now been re-opened at 33 Rue Cherif Pasha. Mrs. and Master Powell sailed from Genoa on the "Canopic" for American, where they will spend the winter.
The Russian Diplomatic Agent and Consul General, Mr. Smyrnoff, has left Italy for St. Petersburg and will not return to Cairo before the 15th prox.
Sir Malcolm Mellwraith has arrived in Cairo from Europe.
Captain Lord Charles Fitz Maurice, second son of Lord Landsdowne, has arrived in Cairo from London.
Mr. Emmanuel Benachi, President of the Hellenic Community of Alexandria, who is staying at his villa at Kephisia in the neighbourhood of Athens is returning to Egypt at the end of the month.
Khalil Pasha Khayat has arrived at Alexandria from Syria.
Among last weeks arrivals at the Savoy Hotel, London, were Nungovich Bey, Rostovitz Bey and Mr. D. Bouboulis. Sabbag Bey has arrived at the Carlton.

div.head: CAIRO HOTEL KING.
div.p: Mr. Charles Baebler is the subject of an interesting study in the "Gil Blas" of Paris, from which we extract the following:-

Celui qui préside a leur évolation (Ghezireh Palace Hotel, Shepheard's Hotel) s'appelle M. Charles Bashiler. C'est une physionomie ou- rieuse, un audacieux, uh ésprit a la fois lucide, poetique et pratique. Il n'a pas 40 ans, c'est le type accompli du gentleman, possédant les qualités de tous les peuples et s'assimilant le gout de chacun d'eux avec une extraordinaire facilité.

C'est M. Chiurles Bachler qui, le pretmiér, in- troduisit I'nsage de l'électricité en Tcare, au temps mythologiqne, s'en fut trop prés du soleil et y brala les se cour- siers, pnisqn'il paratt qu'a 'Epoque les chevaux avaient des ailes. Plus heureax, eo novatenr a pris la fée bleue par la main et lai a fait franchir la Méditerranée. Il a porté aux bords du Nil Is force et la lu- miére, et il y continue son cuvre de moder- nisme. Sous |'impulsion de son intelligence vive, il édifie, il constrait, il transforme. A chaque nation du monde, il demande ce qu'elle posséde d'intelligent, de grand et de beau.
C'est la le but auquel s'est attaché M. Char- les Baehler, et qu'il semble devoir non pas atteindre, mais dépasser.

div.head: A WAKES DIFFICULTY.
div.p: It is rumoured that the constrnotion of the Roman Catholic Church-of St. Joseph, Cairo which has been proceeding daring the last two years has been stopped owing to an objection by the guardians of a tomb of a sheikh, that the church has been erected nearer than the legally prescribed limits for similar edifices to mosques or shrines. The tomb unquestionab- ly exista,but remained unobserved until re- cently, when the New Egyptian Co. demolished the buildings surrounding it and cleared the grounds for sale. If the rumour is accarate and the Wakf carry their objection, there will have been a lamentable oversight on the part of somebody.

div.head: THE "TSUKUBA."
div.p: Our Suez correspondent writes :— Lately several Cairo and Alexandria Buropean and native papers published the alarming news that the Japanese battleship "Tsukuba" was ashore in the Gulf of Suez, south of Ras Garib light- house, and was sabsequently refloated and towed to Suez for repairs. The news is absolu- tely without any foundation whatever, and the battleship in question was never ashore, the was only seen by veveral ships' to be lying for a day off Rav Garib, and this apparently owing practicing purposes.

div.head: BRITISH RIFLE CLUB (ALEX.)
div.p: Members are informed that owing to the impending change of Regiments the Range at Mustapha will not be available for shooting on Saturday next 19th inst. Also that during the remainder of this season, shooting will commence at the 500 yards range, followed by the 600 and finishing at 200 yards.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
(Aujourd'hui a midi)
div.p: Nous avons assisté ce matin A un véritable aéluge d'ordres de vente. I! en pleuvait de partont. Outre ceux de notre bonne ville d'A- lexandrie, il nous tombait incessamment des mets de titres du Caire, en particulier des de Cassa di Seonto et de Delta Land. Bn I'absence caractérisée d'achetenrs que nons avons déjasignalée hier, l'empressement des Vendeurs n'a pu étre satisfait qu'au prix d'une rédnction appréciable de leurs exigences. En core les échanges sont-ils restés clairsémés, ent infimes et disséminés un peu sur totites les valeurs offertes. Li s'agit, bien en- tendu, des titres spéculatifs ; ceax de premier ordre étant pour ainsi dire monopolisés par les places européennes sont restés négligés et rela- tivement soutenus.

La Delta Light fiéchit de 10 5/16 4 10 1/4 et la Daira de13 3/4 4 1311/16. D'autre part, Vobligation Crédit Foncier rétrograde de 300 a 297 l'ancienne et de 253 4 252 la nouvelle ; ce recul, sans gravité par lni-méme puisque letitre est de tout repos, acependant one portée assez significative du fait qu'il ne prend de propor tions sérienses que dans le cas ob |'épargne se trouve acculée & ses derniers retranchements.

En baisse encore les Nungovich Hotels de 16 1/2 & 16 3/8, la Nile Land de 13 & 9 (cette chute de 4 livres en un sen! coup indique assez que le cours antérieur était nominal, comme celui d'une bonne partie de nos papiers), |'Ur baine de 8 7/8 4 33/4, I'Union Fonciére de 4 7/8 & 418/16 et le Crédit Franco-Egyptien de 45/16 a 43/16.
Seule la Khedivial Mail progresse de 4 a4 8/16 laction privilégice et de 21/9 4 22 l'ordi nary.

Parmi les titres d'ordre secondaire, les Mar- kets s'inscrivent @ 2T7/-ex coupon. L'Anglo- Egyptian Spinning baisse de 3/8 a 5/16, la Salt & Soda de 18/6 & 18, la Cassa di Seonto e di Risparmio de 53 450, la Delta Land de 1 19/32.A 1 1/2, les Estates de 21/32 a 19/32, 'le Comptoir de 3 1/32 l'ancienne, 3 1/16 Ia nouyelle et 2 1/8 Ia fondateur, a 2 15/16, 3 et 2 respectivement, la Building Lands de 2 116 A 2 vendeurs, la Levant de 19/32 a 9/16, I'United de 9/32 A 1/4 l'action et de 11/8 a 1 la fondateur et la part de fondateur Sednaoui Zariffa de 4 43 3/8. Seule, dans cette catégorie, l'Allotment reprend de 2 3/16 4 2 3/x l'action et de 55 & 60 P.T. la fondateur.

Le nouvean prix de la Sednaoui Zariffa fon dateur a été déterminé par la vente aux en chéres publiques de 5 fondateurs 4 313 32° Le cas ¢tant pareil pour nombre d'autres valeurs, on voit de quelle envergure sont nos transactions depuis que le marché a terme a été saprimeé.

C'est, en cffet, a cette soppression qu'on attribne, e méme temps qu'aux réalisations plus ou moins forcées, la byisse actuelle— suppression d'aillenrs inévitable puisque les courtiers n'offrent plus en général de surface soffisante. Dans ces conditions on ne peut que se montrer réservé dans les pronostics et ceux qai auront suivi nos conseils de prudence n'auront pas A s'en repentir : se limiter dans ses acquisitions aux bonnes valeurs de tout repos et ne jamais outrepasser ses moyens , en tout cas laisser aux professionnels la manipula tion des titres spéculatifs.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
NOTES BY CRITIQUES
div.p: Le taux de l'escompte libre a Londres est renseigne invarie a 4 1/8 pour cent.

Au Stock-Exchange, le Consolide anglais est reste hier inchange a 82 5/8. L'Unifee a baisse de 1/4 a 102 3/4. La National Bank a retrograde de 1/4 a 22 1/8 et l'Agricole de 1/8 a 8 1/2. La Daira a ete ferme a 13 7/8 et la Delta Light a 10 1/2.
A Paris, le Credit Foncier Egyptien a ete soutenu a 695. La Banque d'Athenes a perdu 1 francs a 111. Les Lots Turcs ont gagne 2 francs a 167.
Ici, nous avons eu un marche quasi-nul avec retrogradation generale dans tous les compartiments.
On s'y attendait du reste vu les cours arrives de Londres ce matin en legere reaction, ce qui montre que de plus en plus notre marche est infeoe a celui de la capitale britannique.

Les cours redeviennent tenants et il est peu probable que ceux qui osent acheter actuellement aient a a'en repentir, car il est naturel de penser qu'une fois les nombreuses execution, auxquelles nous assistons sepuis quelques jours, terminees et les ventes provoquees par les recents appels de fonds cessant, une reprise se produira immanquablement.

Dans le compartiment des Banque, la National Bank baisse a 21 13/16. L'Agricole n'est pas nieux tenue a 8 1/4-5/16. Le Comptoir Financier et Commercial se tasse a 3 et sa part a 2 1/8. L'action Societe Generale Egyptienne revient a 215.

Les Jouissances Eaux du Caire retrofradent a 191. L'Obligation ancienne du Credit-Foncier est ramenee a 299-300 et la nouvelle a 253-254. La Behera reagit a 23 5/8-3/4. La Nile Land est inscrite a 10 (nominal). L'Allotment retombe a 2 1/8-3/16 et la fondateur a P.T. 63. L'Union Fonciere recule a 4 13/16. Les Entreprises Immobilieres et Travaux faiblissent a 2 1/6 et leur part a P.T. 43. La fondateur Heliopolis s'affaisse a 10 7/8.

Dans le groupe des Hotels, les Nungovich sont offertes a 16 1/2-3/4. Les Egyptian Hotels (Baehler) acht moins bien tenues a 6 3/16-1/4. L'Upper Egypt est faible a 2 15/16-3 ainsi que les National Hotels a 2 3/8 et les Excelsior Hotels a 2 en perte de 1/2.
Parmi les petites valeurs, les Estates sont lourdes a 0 5/8-11/16 et l'Ordinary Khedivial Mail progresse a 22/-.
Le "Statist" apprécie comme suit la situa tion monétaire da marché anglais:

"La semaine derniére l'argent a été l'objet d'une bonne demande en raison de la fin du trimestre, mais principalement parce que les envois d'or 4 destination de l'Egypte ont com- mencé a se faire sur une échelle trés considé- rable. L'année derpiére, en septembre, ol expédié 2,000,000 de livres sterling et en octo- bre 4,000,000 de livres sterling en Egypte. 11 fant ne pas perdre de vue que cette année le rendement de la récolte ducotonen Egypte est supérieur a celui de 1906 et que les prix sont également plus élevés. Par conséquent il est raisonnable de prévoir qa'une somme (ale A celle exigée l'année derniére sera nécessaire en 1907 et que 6,000,000 de livres sterling Hor seront retirés de la Banque d'Angleterre d'ici fin octobre, ou platét 4,500,000 liv. st. car en septembre il a été déjA expédié 1,500,000 liv.st. En ontre, le change frangais & son niveau actuel rend avantageox l'envoi d'or de Lon- dres & Paris et c'est une autre raison justifiant le raffermissement des taux monétaires sur lo marché anglais.

D'autre part, il est possible que |'Amérique demande de l'or 4 Londres qui doit se préparer aussi 4 satisfaire les demandes de |' Amérique du Sud. Heureusement, la situation de la Banque d'Angleterre est plus solide qu'il y a un an et les gens les mieux informés croient qu'il u'y aura pas de retraits d'or sérieux a effectaer pour New-York cette année, Quant a la demande pour |'Allemagne, elle parait ¢tre satisfaite pour le moment mais il reste A voir si elle ne se renouvellera pas en décembre. En | ce quiconcerne les Indes, on pense que s'il se produit une demande elle sera médiocre. Dans l'ensemble, la situation est beaucoup plus favo reble qu'il y aun an 4 pareille date et nous avons d'excellentes raisons d'espérer que |'es- compte officiel ne sera pas élevé durant. l'au- tomne.
Carnet de l'actionnaire.

MM. les actionnaires de la 'Société H. de Vries and Boutigny Ltd." sont avisés que le solde dQ sur leurs actions est payable an plus tard le 24 Octobre courant plus les intéréts de retard calculés au taux de 9 | I'an.
Faute par enx d'effectuer ledit paiement dans le délai fixé, il leur sera fait application des art. 20 et 21 des Statats dont la teneur est la suivante

Art. 20. If any Member fail to pay any call or instalment on or before the day appointed for the payment of the same, the Directors may at any time thereafter, during such time as the call or instalment remains unpaid, serve a notice on such Member requiring him to pay the same, together with any interest that may. have accrued and all expenses that may lave been inenrred by the Company by reason of such non-payment.

Art. 21. The notice shall name a day (not being less than fourteen days from the date of the notice) and a place or places on and at which such call or instalment and such interest and expenses as aforesaid are to be paid. The notice shall also state that in the event of non-payment at or before the time and at the place appointed, the shares in respect of which the call was made or instalment is payable will be liable to be forfeited.

div.head: Administration of Ports & Lights.
NOTICE TO MARINERS
MEDITERRANEAN.
div.p: The master of the Dutch Steamer "Madiera" has reported having passed, a red oval buoy adrift in Lat. 32, 36 N. Long. 27, 27 E.
This position is approx N. 18 W. (mag) 96 miles from Ras Kanais.
The date of passing the bouy is not given but it was probably October 16th.
Herbert J. Gedge.
Alexandria, October 16th, 1907. 31119-2-1

div.head: The Egyptian Salt and Soda Company, Ltd.
div.p: The Shareholders of the Egyptian Salt & Soda Company Limited are informed that, by decision of the Board an interin dividend of 39 milleiemes per share being 4 per cent, will be payable on and after November 1st 1907 at the Offices of the National Bank of Egypt at Cairo, Alexandria and London on presentation of Coupon No 7.

Messieurs les Actionnaires de l'Egyptian Salt & Soda Company Limited sont informes que par decision du Conseil d'Administration un dividende interimaire de 39 milliemes par action soit 4% leur sera paye a partir du ler Novembre 1907 aux Caisses de la National Bank of Egypt au caire, a Alexandrie et a Londres, contre remise du coupon No 7.
Alexandrie, le 16 Octobre 1907. 31116-3-1

div.head:
THE FONTANET DISASTER.
665 KILLED AND INJURED.
OVER A THOUSAND HOMELESS.

div.p: 25 persons have been killed, 40 are dying, 600 have been injured, and 1,200 are homeless as a result of the explosion in the powder works at Fontanet (Indiana). Every buildng within a radius of half a mile has been wrecked.
(Reuter)

div.head:
THE PERSIAN SITUATION.
DISTURBANCES AT KERMAN.

div.p: The "Times" learns from Teberan that disorders have taken place at Kerman. Seven persons have been killed and many wounded. Refugees have taken shelter in the British telegraph office. The Russian Consulate and the British Legation have made representations to the President of Parliament.
(Reuter)

div.head:
MULAY HAFID'S ENVOYS.
RECEPTION REFUSED BY GERMANY.

div.p: The Foreign Office has refused to receive Mulay Hafid's envoys. They have proceeded to Rome.
(Reuter)
The Minister of Foreign Affairs has refused to receive the envoys of Mulay Hafid.
(Havas)

div.head:
RAINSTORMS IN SCOTLAND.
GREAT DAMAGE DONE.

div.p: Torrential rainstorms have occurred in the south of Scotland resulting in much destruction of grain and sheep. The railways are interrupted by portions being washed out. Some of the Glasgow suburban lines are flooded to the extent of 7 feet.
(Reuter)

div.head:
THE FRENCH FLOODS.
CONTINUATION OF RAIN.

div.p: The rains are aggravating the situation in the mid-regions and the Loire.
(Havas)

div.head:
SHREWSBURY TRAIN DISASTER.
TRAIN RAN AWAY.

div.p: It is stated that the train wrecked in the Shrewsbury disaster was travelling at 50 miles an hour instead of slowing up, as it should have stopped. The signalman at the station received a message that the train was running away.
(Reuter)

div.head:
A NEW DRINK BILL.
SAFEGUARDING THE MODERATES.

div.p: Mr. Lloyd George, speaking at Manchester, said that the Government meant to concetrate its energy in 1908 on a great bill aimed at excessive drinking, but safeguarding the moderate drinker.
(Reuter)

Cesarewitch Stakes, 1, Demure: 2. The White Knight; 3. Wuffy. Betting 4 to 1 Demure; 100 to 8 The White Knight; 10 to 1 Wuffy, 13 ran. Won by three quarters of a length. Three lengths between second and third.
(Reuter)

The Austrian and Hungarian Premiers yesterday submitted the "Ausgleich" to their respective Parliaments. It provides for a Court of Arbitration to settle economic disputes; it grants to Hungary concessions with reference to the consumption taxes; it settles the bank railway questions satisfactorily for both parties, and provides for 2% increase in Hungary's quota of the common expenditure.
(Reuter)
The Austro-Hungarian compromise has been placed in the Chamber amidst the applauds of the Deputies.
(Havas)
All the newspapers reports an improved state of the Emperor's health.
(Havas)
There is a distinct improvement in the Emperor's health.
(Reuter)
The COnference has voted the declaration of obligatory arbitrage.
(Havas)

(Reuter)
M. Isvolsky has arrived here on a 10 days' stay.
(Reuter)
M. Isvolsky has arrived.
(Havas)

(Reuter)
The second degree elections appear to give predominance in the Duma to the supporters of the Government
(Havas)
The police have arrested 6 of the signatories of an anti-militarist manifesto inciting conscripts to desert.
(Reuter)

div.head: MINERAL AND AERATED WATERS IN EGYPT.
div.p: We would draw the attention of our readers who are now returning to Egypt from their summer vacations, to the absolute necessity of using only pure mineral and aerated waters.

Throughout the summer, the less fortunate of us who have had to remain in thirsty Egypt, have seen the great amount of fever which has been the result of an impure water supply, and we therefore most strongly advise all our readers to use more aerated waters.

In this country @ great menace to the public health is the large number of manufacturers of mineral waters in a small way, who supply mysterions and deadly concoctions at a low figure. To counteract these we have only one firm, the name of which alone is a guarantee ot absolute purity and all that is hygenic. This is the well known firm of Mr. N. Spathis, whose high class Soda Water, Lemonade Ginger Beer, Ginger Ale, Lime Juice and Soda, etc, ete, are the best that can possibly be made, not only in Egypt, but the world over.

A visit to Mr. Spathis' manutactory will convince any doubters, of the excellence of these minerals, the whole of the machinery heing the most up to-date, the water perfectly pure, only the very best ingredients used, and | the whole of the working being carried ont under the strictest supervision and with the utmost cleanliness.

div.head: Money Market.
div.p: With the steady efflux of gold to Egypt and other quarters, and the prospect of a contimance of the drain upon the Bank of England, the appreciation in discount rates now noticeable is in the natural order of things. The minimum rate for three months' bills yesterday was 4 1/16, and in a number of cases 4 1/8 per cent, was demanded.

As we were able to forecast in our last article, the shipment of gold to Egypt on Saturday totalled £1,200,000, and we hear on good authority that a further large sum ranging from £1,000,000 to £1,250,000 will be withdrawn for the same quarter to-night. In the corresponding week last year the ship- ment amounted to £1,010,000, bringing up the season's total to that date to £4,170,000. Assnming that the top figure of £1,250,000 above-mentioned represents to-night's with- drawal, the total for the preseat season will be only £3,450,000 or £720,000 less than last year.

Provincial demands for coin again appear as a prominent factor in the Bank return this week. Over £800,000 has gone into country circulation, so that, with the exportation of £1,036,000, the stock of coin and bullion is reduced by £1,855,000. There is, however, a contraction of £858,000 in the Active Note Circulation, making the reduction in the reserve £1,497,000. The reserve now stands at £24,139,000, which is still well above the total in the corresponding week of 1906, when it was as low as £18,290,000. The present proportion to the current liabilities, 46 1/2 per cent., compares with 354 per cent. last year.
The quotation for bar gold to-day is 77/10 1/8. an advance of 1/8 on the week.

div.head: Silver.
div.p: The silver market is very depressed, and the price yesterday for immediate delivery fell away to 29 7/16 per ounce, which is the lowest quotation since March, 1906. The price for forward delivery is 29 11/16.

div.head: The Stock Markets.
div.p: This has been another very unsatisfactory week on the Stock Exchange, and the forther renewal of liquidation, with a consequent fall in values, has been such as to cause extreme disappointment to those who had looked to the autumn to bring a revival in investment business. The operations connected with the adjustment of the account alone saved the market from absolute idleness at the beginning, but during the past two or three days there has been a good deal of pressure to sell. The heavy liquidation on the New York stock exchange is largely responsible for this state of things, and markets have been almost entirely under this adverse influence. The tightening of the money position in the States has caused the banks to exercise greater discrimination in the matter of loans, and their attitude in refusing to accept industrial stocks as security caused the latter to be thrown on the market in large blocks. Prices in consequence slumped to very low levels, in fact in two or three cases the quotations in Wall Street yesterday morning were the lowest registered for some years.
The tone here during the early part of yesterday was extremely weak, but towards the close of a rather more confident feeling prevailed.

The Egyptian section, it is satisfactory to note, continues to make steady progress, in spite of the depressing influences prevailing all around, and there has been an appreciable amount of investment buying of the leading securities during the past week.
The tendency of markets has again been unsatisfactory to-day.

div.head: Consols.
div.p: Home Government securities, after a firm opening, have again assumed a weak appearance, and Consols have further declined. A fall of 3/16 yesterday put them down to 82 3/4 for cash and 82, 15/16 for the account, a loss of 1/4 on our last quotation.
To-day Consols have lost 1/8 for cash and 3/16 for the account.

div.head: Foreign Bonds.
div.p: For the most part international stocks have fairly successfully resisted the adverse influences at work in other sections, although the reports regarding the unsatisfactory state of the Emperor of Austria's health created an uneasy feeling yesterday, which cause a slight falling away. Russian Fours lost 1/2 to 75 1/4 and the Fives 1/4 to 88.
Japanese have been quiet. Several issues have shed about 1/8, but the first Fives left off last night at an advance of 1/4, 10, 1/4.
Russian Fours, are down 1/4 to-day, and two Japanese issues have given way 1/8.

div.head: Home Ralls.
div.p: Shares in the home railway section have keen neglected, and have moved somewhat irregularly. It is not expected that there will be any active dealings in these stocks until the dispute between the companies and the Amalgamated Society of Railway Servants has | been settled. What will be the outcome of this it is increasingly diffieult to forecast. A report was published the other day to the effect that the companies would refuse to meet the men's officials in conference, and the latter have retaliated by announcing that, in the event of such a refusal, the Parliamentary Committee of the Trades Unions Congress, the General Federation of Trades Unions, and the Labocr party will meet in joint conference to determine what steps shall be taken. This morning there are dark hints from certain quarters that the Government may interfere to prevent a strike.

Meanwhile increases in traffics go on space, and the returns this week are better than ever. In the case of the North Western there is an increase of £24.000, which comes on top of a gain in the corresponding week last year of £4,000, and the Great Western add £21,300 to last year's increase of £6,100. Pleasant surprise was caused by the announcement of a gain of £1,400 by the Brighton line, following one of £4,000 in the same week of 1906. A demand for the shares was the result, and the "bears" being caught short, the price for the "A" stock rose from 74 1/2 to 77 1/4, closing at 76 1/2. The quotation has since declined, and closed yesterday at 75 1/4.
With the exception of a recovery of 1/4 in Brighton "A," movements in home railway shares have to-day generally been against holders.

div.head: Americans.
div.p: The break in Wall Street referred to above has natarally had a very distarbing eftect upon the American market here, and although com- paratively speaking, there has not been a great deal MP selling on local account, the continued liquidation from Holland has been a depressing feature. Until the money position in the States shows some signs of eas- ing, and the Wall Street market develops an appearance of something like steadiness, a recovery of any importance is not to be expect- ed here, as the market has not sofficient initiative to strike ont an independent course.

Yesterday at the opening the tone was very nervous, but later improved, and closed below the worst. Grand Trunks rallied sharply on the favourable remarks of the charman at the company's meeting, and the Third Preference closed with an advance of 2 1/4 at 68 3/4.
Business in Americans has been restricted to-day. Souther Pref. have advanced 1 to 51, Southern Pacific and Unions 1/4 to 81 1/2 and 128 respectively.

div.head: Egyptians.
div.p: Fluctuations in the Egyptian market daring the past week have been within a Very narrow margin, and there has again been good buying of investment securities, interspersed with 4 little liquidation on both local and Continental account.

Daira Deferred have again been in request, and last night closed buyers at 73 1/21. They close to-night 7 3/76. The Ordinary have been as good as 14}, but left off last night at 13 15/16. They are now 13 7/8-14 1/8.

National Banks have suffered slightly from the general liquidation which has been going on, but otherwise the price list discloses no outstanding feature. Nationals are quoted to-night at 22 1/8 at which they show little change on the week.

The tone in this market is wonderfully steady, considering the fact that the "carry- over" disclosed heavy differences in certain speculative stocks which would have to be met, and which, as is usually the case, gave rise to apprehensions of possible trouble. When financial conditions improve a substantial recovery in Egyptian stocks may be expected.

div.head: Mining.
div.p: The opening of a newaccount synchronised with an improvement in the tone of South Africans, and on Tuesday, the list throughout showed an all-round advance. The upward movement was checked on Wednesday, bat yesterday the market received another fillip from the publication of the gold output for September. Although this showed a decrease on the previous month, owing to the difference of a day in the lengths ofthe respective months, the total of 538,084 ounces was only 16,993 less than for August. The increased profits shown by a large proportion of the individual companies is a very pleasing feature of the return, and cause for satisfaction is also to be found in the increase of available native labour.
To-day Kaffirs have been irregular, but Rhodesians are firmer.
Egyptian mining shares are unchanged.
The closing prices to-night are as follows:

div.head: EGYPTIAN POLITICS.
LETTER TO SIR ELDON GORST.
div.p: The Egyptian notables who recently addressed a petition to the Khedive asking for the bestowal of constitutional government, have sent a letter to Sir Eldon Gorst, in which, according to "Al Ahram," they formulate the following demands:-

1-The abolotion of the agreement concluded the 1st January, 1899, between the English and Egyptian governments and the submission of the Sudan to the Egyptian Government pursuants to the Turkish firmans and international agreements.
2- The restoration to Egypt of her ports such as Massaouah and Zeila, as by virtue of the firmans they belong to Egypt.

(Massouah is now the capital of Italian Eretria, Zeila belongs to British Somaliland. In 1899 Massouah was ceded to Egypt, but in 1885 on the instigation of Great Britain the Italians seized the port and made it the base of their expansive enterprise in Ethiopis.)

3- The creation of an Egyptian Parliament which will manage Egyptian affairs and execute the laws in co-operation with the Government. The electoral test should be intellectual capacity and not wealth.
4- The release of the Denshawai prisoners, and the abolition of the decree of 1895 regarding the Special Tribunal.

5- The extension of the jurisdiction of the Mixed Courts by giving them the authority to judge delicts and crimes, and by confiding to the Mixed Court of Appeal the duty of reshaping and adapting the European Code.
6- The abolition of the posts of Advisers and the granting of official freedom to the Ministers.
7- The gradual substitution for foreign functionaries in the Government service of capable Egyptians.
8- The arrangement of the financial organisation on a stable basis which will put an end to economic waste.
9- The deliverance of the Egyptian treasury from the expenses occasioned by the presnce of the Army of Occupation, this army having no longer any raison d'etresince 1890.
10- The elaboration of an anti-immigration law by which undesirable aliens will be excluded from Egypt.
11- The creation of a Municipality in Cairo.
12- The creation of a University in the capital.
13- The creation of Chambers of Commerce.
14- The development of free compulsory education in Arabic.
15- The creation of a Ministry of Agriculture and a Commercial School.
16- The extension of the domain in industrial and agricultural education, and of Egyptian missions.
17- There establishment of the night section of the Khedivial Law School and the creation of a section for the doctorate.
18- The holding of primary and secondary certificate examinations twice per annum.
19- The radical reformation of the Mehkemehs.
20- The reform of the police.
21- The elaboration of a law for the Stock Exchange.
22- The minting of coin in Egypt as formerly.
23- Removal of the restrictions on tobacco cultivation.
24- The giving of complete liberty to Egyptian pilgrims.
25- The substitution of Nile water for that of Rod-el-Farag whose deficiencies are amply recognised.

div.head: MUNICIPALITE D'ALEXANDRIE
AVIS
div.p: L'adjudication pour la fourniture de 400 grilles pour puisards et de 200 regards de visite a ete revoyee jusqu'au 5 Novembreprochain.
Le cautionnement est fixe a L.Eg. 75.
Le cahier des charges est depose au bureau Technique ou il peut etre consulte par les interesses tous les jours de 9h. a midi, les jours teries exceptes.
Les offres devront etre adresses sous pli cachete a Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalite avant le 5 Novembre 1907.
Elles pourront egalement etre deposees en seance de la Delegation le meme jour a 5h. p.m.
L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention: "Soumission" pour fourniture grilles et puisards".

Le cautionnement ou le recu d'une banque, d'apres les conditions du cahier des charges, devra etre remis separement au Service de la Comptabilite general avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 5 Novembre 1907a midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci=dessus sera ecartee.
Alexandrie le 14/10/07.
Le Vice-President:
31104-3-2(signe) Dr Schiess.

div.head: Sudan Government
NOTICE.
div.p: Persons importing Egyptian Labourers to work in the Sudan are recommended to enter into a written contract with them. This contract should be explained and signed by the Labourers is the presences of an official or other reliable witness.

div.head: SUDAN IRRIGATION SERVICE.
NOTICE
div.p: Applications (in writing only) for places as clerks in the Sudan Branch of the Egyptian Irrigation Service will be received at the Ministry of Public Works up to the 25th October by the Inspector General of Irrigation for the Sudan.
Some educational qualifications and a good knowledge of English is essential. Pay L.E. 8 to L.E. 15 per month according to qualifications.

Applications should state qualifications and experience and give references and should be accompanied by copies of certificates; and should be addressed to the Inspector General of Irrigation for the Sudan, Public Works Ministry, Cairo, in envelopes labelled "Application for post of clerk."

div.head: Administration des Chemins de Fer de l'Etat Egyptien
AVIS
div.p: L'Administration a l'honneur de porter a la connaissance du Public qu'il sera procede, le Vendredi dix-huit Octobre courant, a neuf heures du matin aux Magasins Generaux de Boulac (Cairo), a la Vente aux encheres publiques, suivant Kaimat Mazad, de cent tonnes environ de vieux bois et dechets hors d'usage provenant des travaux du Service des Ponts, qui se trouvent an chantier du Service des Ponts a Ramlet Boulac (Caire), ou on peut les examiner chaque jour de neuf heures du matin a midi, les Dimanches et jours feries exceptes.

Les conditions de vente relatives a ces materiaux peuvent etre consulteesau Bureau de Mr. le Chef du Service des Magasins Generaux a Boulac, Caire, chaque jour de neuf heures du matin a une heure p.m. les Dimanches et jours feries exceptes

Pour etre admis a concourir, le soumissionnaire devra, au prealable, verser a la Caisse Centrale de l'Administration au Caire, une somme de L.E. 10 (dix Livres Egyptiennes) a titre de depot provisoire. Le soumissionnaire declare adjudicataire devra parfaire cette somme jusqu'a concurrence du 10% (dix pour cent) du montantde l'offre agreee et enlever a ses frais les lots qui lui seront adjuges dans un delai de trente jours a compter de la date de l'avis d'acceptation de son offre.

Les offres pourront etre taites sur papier timbre de trente milliemes, si l'interesse ne peut pas assister aux encheres publiques, et dans ce cas la soumission ainsi que le recu du versement du depot provisoire seront adresses par la poste sous pli recommande a:
"Mr. le Chef du Service des Magasins Genraux des Chemins de Fer de l'Etat a Boulac Caire"
et sous double enveloppe, l'interieure portant la suscription suivante:
"Offre pour Achat de vieux bois et de dechets."
Toute offre faite ou deposee ulterieure ment au jour et a l'heure ci=dessus designes ne sera pas prise en consideration.
L'Administration ne s'engage pas a accepter les prix les plus eleves ni a donner suite aux soumissions presentees. Elle se reserve le droit de diviser la vente.
Le Caire, le 9 Octobre 1907.

div.head: AVIS
div.p: L'Administration des Chemins de Fer et Telegraphes de l'Etat a l'honneur de porter a la connaissance du Public qu'elle recevra jusqu'au Lundi 16 Decembreprochain, a midi au plus tard, des offre pour la construction des maconneries de tondation et des maconneries d'elevation des piles et culees, ainsi que la fourniture, la construction et le montage de la partie metallique d'un nouveau pont a deux voies, a establir a Kocheicha, au point kilometrique 95+740 de la lignedu Caire a Louxor et ce conformement a toutes les conditions generales, a la description generale des travaux, aux clauses generales de l'entreprise et aux desseins annexes au cahier des Charges relatif a cette adjudication, duquel un exemplaire complet sera mis a la disposition des intresses sur leurs demandes au bureau de mM> le Chef du Service des Magasins Generaux de Boulac (Caire) et a celui de M. l'Inspecteur des Magasins Generaux a Alexandrie contre paiement de £1 (Une Livre Sterling).

Toute personne desirant prendre part a cette adjudication, devra en meme temps qu'elle presentera son offre et sous peine de nullite de celle-ci, effecteur a la Caisse de l'Administration des CHemins de Fer un cantionnement provisoire en especes ou en titres de la Dette Egyptienne de la valeur de L.E. 500 (Livres Egyptiennes cinq cents). Le soumissionnaire declare adjudicataire devra, dans un delai de huit jours apres l'acceptation en principe de son offre, deposer dans la susdite caisse nn cautionnement de Livres Egyptiennes deux mille cinq cents.

Les soumissions devront etre accompagnees d'une feuille de papier timbre de trente milliemes, sinsi que du recu du versement du cautionnement provisoire. Elles seront adresses sous pli recommande et cachete a:
Monsieur le Directeur General des Chemins de Fer de l'Etat au Caire (Egypte)
et sous double enveloppe, l'interieure portant la suscription auivante:
"Offre pour la construction d'un Pont a deux voies a Kocheicha".

L'Administration se reserve le droit de ne donner sucune suite aux soumissions presentees, quel que soit le prix soumis: elle sera libra de choisir l'offre qui lui paraltra la plus scantageuse, notamment au point de vue du delai d'execution, sans etre tenue d'accepter celle qui sera la plus basse.
Le Caire, le 7 Octobre 1907. 31064-2-2
